awd_titl_txt: Identifying and Correcting Quantum Systems with Initial System-Environment Correlations
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum information processing holds promise for more secure communication, for solving computing problems that can't be solved in a timely manner on classical machines, and for simulating a variety of quantum many-body systems using quantum systems. However, to realize these advances, one needs to understand how quantum systems interact with various environments.  This project will aid in the development of quantum technologies by adding to the theoretical approaches that can be used to plan optimum control of quantum systems. In particular, this project will investigate how to avoid errors in quantum computation that arise because of prior correlations between quantum systems and their environment.  This is important because understanding how quantum systems behave in various environments will lead to new knowledge in several fields ranging from biological systems, to materials science, fundamental physics, and molecular scale machines.  This work could thus enable better health care, better materials for use in industry as well as everyday life, and a variety of technologies that operate on the molecular scale.  This project will train students to use quantum physics techniques and to understand the physical concepts.  Outreach activities intended to reach a broader audience will also be undertaken as part of this project.
 
In order to achieve reliable quantum information processing we must develop methods for controlling quantum systems.  This includes modeling quantum systems that are noisy due to interactions with their environment.  A standard method for describing the evolution of open quantum systems is to assume the environment and the system in question are initially decoupled, evolve under some joint evolution, and then average over the environmental degrees of freedom to obtain an effective noisy evolution.  This method of modeling the evolution is inadequate under some conditions such as strong coupling and quantum systems that are initially coupled to their environment.  The objective of this work is to aid in the development of quantum technologies by helping understand and describe requirements for practical modeling and error prevention strategies in these circumstances by understanding the limitations of previous work and finding ways to describe systems that do not satisfy the standard assumptions.  Both theoretical and numerical work will be employed to achieve the results and describe specific examples that are relevant to experiment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our work on “Identifying and Correcting Quantum Systems with Prior Correlations” has resulted in several key results. 

1)       We found that some of the work in the literature was misleading.  A former paper claimed that errors in quantum computing systems could be described by “maps” that are “not completely positive.”  These terms have technical definitions, but they are believed to be the result of quantum systems that have prior correlations with their environment.  Our study indicates that such evolutions are not always due to prior correlations and that the previous work does not give sufficient conditions for the correction of these errors as claimed. 

2)      Following our discovery, we found sufficient conditions to remedy these errors.

3)      We developed a new method for identifying prior correlations by only measuring the system.  This means that we do not need to measure the bath that interacts with our quantum system in order to discover correlations.  This could be very helpful for experimentalists trying to identify errors and properly address them. 

4)      We found a way to identify correlations using explicit mappings from the states of the system (in terms of the coherence vector or polarization vector description of the density matrix).  Our result simplifies and gives explicit formulas that aid in the identification and comparison of correlations by enabling an explicit computational encoding of these formulas.

5)      We developed methods to eliminate errors in a mechanical oscillator using “Leakage Elimination Operators” (LEOs).  LEOs were developed by the PI, Lian-Ao Wu and Daniel Lidar twenty years ago. 

6)      We investigated quantum systems that couple to their environment in a particular (non-Markovian) noise and that the noise, in this case caused by heat transfer, did not necessarily impede adiabatic state evolution.   This means that, in some cases, we can speed up some quantum interactions without the worry of system-bath interactions destroying the evolution.    

7)      Sometimes transformations of quantum states can be described mathematically, but are not able to be physically implemented.  There are mathematical methods that give new transformations that are able to be implemented physically.  We found some general methods for modifying the transformations such that they are “more physical” in the sense that they can be physically implemented.  (Specifically, we were able to find completely positive maps that approximate maps that are not completely positive.) 

In addition to this work, we have several results that are not yet published.  These include, but are not limited to, mathematical decompositions of SU(6) (transformations between qubits and higher-dimensional states), certain measurements do not remove correlations between a system and its environment, a generalization of the correlation detection method we developed, and examples of quantum systems with prior correlations. 

 

Effects of COVID:  Unfortunately, even though this is theory work, COVID prevented in-person meetings within the group and travel for collaboration.  These were quite detrimental to the work. 

 

 

Broader Impacts:

Quantum computers would enable the solution of some problems that are intractable on classical machines.  However, they are still under development and are not currently fully functional.  The detection and elimination of noise are currently the most important goals of the development of fully functioning quantum computers.

We believe our results will enable the detection of correlations between a system and bath and thus enable the detection of noise in quantum systems.    

In addition to the detection, we have developed error-correcting code conditions for transformations that are not completely positive.  Such transformations could represent errors that arise from systems that have prior correlation with their environment.  Our work provides sufficient conditions for the detection and correction of quantum errors of this type. 

Our work has implications for the development of quantum computers as well as helping to prepare students for work in the quantum industry.

Journal-ref: J. Phys. A: Math. Theor. 54 505302 (2021)

5. arXiv:2104.01695
